security: Several documents discuss the protection of cryptonyms, pseudonyms, cable numbers, file numbers, and employee names. For example, a memo discusses the release of the IJDECANTER cryptonym, arguing it "would provide an identifiable benefit to the Russian counterintelligence effort and concomitant damage to US intelligence interests." It suggests substituting a fictitious cryptonym instead. Another memo details that the release of file numbers would reveal the methodology by which we file/store and retrieve information. which is still in practice today and thus we cannot approve it on a blanket basis.
summary: Collection of memorandums primarily concerning guidelines for releasing information related to the JFK assassination, specifically addressing the handling of cryptonyms, pseudonyms, file numbers, and employee names. It reveals the CIA's deliberations with the ARRB regarding the extent of redactions and the reasoning behind protecting certain information.
summary_one_paragraph: This collection of memorandums from 1993 to 1998 outlines CIA policies and considerations regarding the release of JFK assassination records, particularly concerning cryptonyms, pseudonyms, file numbers, and employee names. It details discussions between the CIA and the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) regarding redaction practices, the protection of intelligence sources and methods, and the potential damage to national security from releasing sensitive information. Key issues include the protection of the IJDECANTER cryptonym to prevent Russian counterintelligence gains, the balancing act between transparency and safeguarding ongoing intelligence operations, and the handling of William Pawley's relationship with the CIA.
title: Release of JFK Assassination Records
recipient: Chief, Historical Review Group, Chief, Information Management Service, Director, Center for the Study of Intelligence, Linda Flor, Jeremy Gunn, Bob Skwirot
sender: John Berg, Joanne Harris, Barry Harrelson, David G. Marwell, Fredrick C. Wickham, Jr., Barry Harrelson, Frieda Omasta, Frieda Omasta, Lee S. Strickland, Charles A. Briggs-Y-'
